text: - Hello, everybody.

Welcome to Ten Minute
Tutorial for Research.
Today we'll talk about

selling your quantum
solutions on AWS Marketplace.
My name is Nihit Pokhrel.
I'm a partner solutions architect
in the High Performance Computing team.
And I'm joined today by Joseph Shih,

who's a partner solutions
architect in AWS Marketplace team.

In the next 10 minutes, Joseph
will do a quick presentation

about AWS Marketplace,
and then I'll follow up
with some frequently asked questions.
Joseph over to you.
- Thank you Nihit.

So AWS Marketplace is a
curated digital catalog

for third party software
where you can find by

deploy and manage third party
software, data products,

as well as services to
build your businesses on.

So we're gonna talk about
how you as a seller of
quantum algorithms can sell your products

on Marketplace, and Marketplace
has different product types
and those kind of dictate
how you would package your product.

So in general, the
product types that we have
there are two main categories.
And the first is that the products
and software that deploy directly
into the buyers AWS account.
So these are software that run

in the buyers' account without
the seller's involvement.

And the first group we
have are single AMIs.
And AMIs are Amazon Machine Images.

They are your virtual
machines that can be deployed
onto EC2 instances in the AWS account.
And EC2, Elastic Compute, are services
that can run virtual machines.

We also have container
product types in Marketplace.

And docker container
images that can deploy
in the buyer's AWS account.

There is also SageMaker
resources, such as model package
and algorithms that can also be deployed
into the buyer's account.

Then you have product
types that are hosted
and maintained by the sellers.

And these include the
SaaS, where the buyers

will directly consume the
product in the seller's account

without having to deploy
any infrastructure
in the buyer's account.

There's also the API data
sets for AWS Data Exchange.

AWS Data Exchange is a
feature in the AWS Marketplace

where data providers can sell
their data in various ways.

And one of them is via an
API that they would host.

So today we're gonna
focus mostly on the AMIs,
containers, SaaS, and the API data sets.

How to package an AMI,
the Amazon Machine Images,

is you have your instance,
your VM that's running,
and you create an image based off that.
That image is then given to Marketplace,
and when buyers go and subscribe to it
they're given access to take that image
and deploy it onto an EC2 instance
to run that virtual machine.

There's also single AMI
with cloud formation.
And cloud formation is a way to describe
and deploy services in AWS.

So you may have AWS services
such as a relational database.

You might have some storage
services that you're using
that your software depends on.

So any of those can be
bundled into the product.
So you would provide us a template
and those are then made available
to the buyers to deploy the AMI,
along with those additional services
to provide that one click experience.
There's also multi AMI
and the only difference here is that
you have multiple different instances

and you wanna publish
multiple different images
into the Marketplace.
And those also are accompanied

by a template that can
help deploy those instances

and other AWS services
that the software needs.

Moving on to containers,
packaging containers.
In AWS Marketplace, the containers
that are published are published into

a repository that's
hosted by AWS Marketplace.
So when you go into your packaging motion,

you would push container
images that buyers would need

into this repository
managed by AWS Marketplace.

And your buyers who have
subscribed would have
the ability to pull those images.
And to help them deploy it on the various
container orchestration platforms
available to them in their account.

You as a seller can provide
them with deployment templates.
So those can be helm charts,
those can be usage instructions,
those can be cloud formation templates,

anything that'll help them
deploy that onto clusters
that they're gonna run your containers on.
Your software will also need to integrate
with AWS Marketplace APIs
for some billing integration there.

For SaaS, when the buyer
comes to AWS Marketplace

they agree to purchase
upfront your SaaS contracts
or agree to your priceless
when they sign up for your SaaS product.

So SaaS products are hosted
in your seller account.

So this is not something
that they would deploy
into their buyer account.

There isn't really any
infrastructure for them to deploy.
Everything is done through you.
So in that case the buyer,

after subscribing,
would then be redirected

to your landing page,
your SaaS application.

Your SaaS application
would then need to capture
a token that they can call the APIs with

to find out who the customer
ID is, who the customer is,
and the customer ID,
and the product that they have purchased.
With that information,
you can call another API to understand
what did the buyer purchase up front?

And how many units of
that that they purchase.

Furthermore, with that
same customer information,
you can then report additional usage
that is outside of the contracts,
or if it's a subscription product
where it's all purely pay as you go,
then you would report those usage

to AWS Marketplace so
that Marketplace can then
charge the customer on their bill.
There's also a SNS topic,
which is a simple notification service
that you can subscribe to,

to keep up to date of any
changes to their subscription
or the contracts they have purchased.
And furthermore, once any changes happen
you can call our APIs again
to understand what they have upgraded to
or any changes in that case.

There are API data sets
for AWS Data Exchange.
So AWS Data Exchange allows data providers
to provide data in various ways.
One of which is an S3 bucket for example.
Where if I have a bunch of CSV files,
then I can put them into a S3 bucket

and publish that through
AWS Data Exchange.

And the buyers would then
pull those data files out.
Now, what if I as a seller want to publish
more of the dynamic data?

As a seller, you can then
publish an API instead.
So this is very similar to the SaaS way
except with the API data set,

you don't really need to
manage the identity there.
It really isn't a token for you to capture
to understand who the customer is.
What you essentially need,
it was just an Amazon API gateway
that will be in front of your application.

And to have responses,
to receive requests,

and respond in certain ways
that the Data Exchange expects.
And what's behind the API gateway is,
anything you would like to use.
So that could be Lambda functions,

that connect to other
services and DynamoDB.

So this is very similar to
how SaaS is done, except

that you don't have to manage
about each individual user.
You will get some identifiers that come

through the API gateway,
but then the idea is
that you're just providing that service.
So everything's proxy through API gateway

and you don't have to worry
about identity in this case.
And that brings us to the close
of our different product types.
- Thank you, Joseph.

Now, I have a couple of
questions that customers
and partners have asked me before.

We will paste the links to
some of these question...
Answers to some of these questions.

So please do not worry about
writing everything down.
The very first question,

can I offer free trials
for my software offering?
- Yeah, that's a good question.
Depending on the product type,
there are some free trial features.
For example the AMI product type,

you can set up a free
trial where the buyer

is not charged your software
fee for X amount of days

and they can run one
instance, for example.
In other product types,
there's different ways to do free trials,

and some product types
don't support free trials.
So it really depends on that product type.
- Okay, thank you.
And what about billing?
Will AWS bill my customers directly?
- Yes. So AWS Marketplace's expectation
is the buyer will pay AWS Marketplace.

And AWS Marketplace will
then provide the software
that's deployed into the buyer's account.

If it's a SaaS, then
the buyer will then go
to your SaaS to consume the product.

But AWS Marketplace
will handle the billing

and allow buyers to then
pay with one AWS bill.
So that's also a benefit for buyers.
- Okay. Thank you.

Now, a couple more questions
and these are quantum specific.
So where will my solution be listed?

Is there a designated page
where quantum computing
solutions will be listed on Marketplace?

- There isn't a quantum
computing category page
or list of products in Marketplace today.
However, I believe it's going to go under

high performance computing
at the the moment.
And in the future, that may change.
- Okay. Thank you.
Knowing that quantum is a very new field,
it's an emerging technology.
And every engagement involves some kind of

professional service
and consulting services.

So in this case, can I
list my quantum focus
professional services on Marketplace?
- Yes, you can.
The only requirement is that

you have some software
product on AWS Marketplace

and then you can publish
a professional service
listing on Marketplace and then charge

for professional services on
top of your software solution.
- Okay. All right. Thank you.
One more question.
Say if I wanted IP protection guaranteed

from AWS Marketplace,
what method should I pick?

- Yeah, that's a very
interesting question.
So IP protection is one of

importance to the sellers
often that we speak with.
So looking at different product types
we have on the screen here.
The single AMI's, the containers,
the SaaS, and the API data sets.
So with AMI product types,

the buyer has full access to
your virtual machine image.

So that means that they
can look inside and be...
Look inside your volumes,
they can inspect your volumes.
Similar with the container images,
they can inspect the layers.
In fact, the container images are your
run of the mill docker containers.
They can be downloaded,

and pulled to a desktop
and inspected there.

So with the software that's
deployed in the buyer's account

namely the AMI and containers,
there's no really way

a way to protect your IP there,
your intellectual property.

With the products like
SaaS and API data sets,

those are where you can protect
your intellectual property

because those run inside
your seller account
and you expose what you want to expose

to the buyer and when
they consume your product.
- Okay, thank you.
So with all this information,
as a seller where do I get started?

- Yeah. So if you go
to the AWS Marketplace,
you can click sell on AWS Marketplace,
this is the link at the top right,
and log into an AWS account.
So the only thing you really need
to get a seller account
is to sign up for an AWS account
and agree to some terms and services.
If you wanna sell paid products
there are some additional steps such as
your tax entity and bank accounts.

There's gonna be a link
in the descriptions
that'll explain the requirements
for setting up a seller account.
So look out for that.
- All right. Thank you.
That's all we had Joseph.
Thank you for joining us

and answering questions
about AWS Marketplace.
- Absolutely. Thank you Nihit.
